examples: Can I bum a smoke off you?; I need to go buy some smokes.

senses.sense: (colloquial, uncountable) Anything to smoke (e.g. cigarettes, marijuana, etc.)
examples: Hey, you got some smoke?

senses.sense: (colloquial, countable, never plural) An instance of smoking a cigarette, cigar, etc.; the duration of this act.
examples: I'm going out for a smoke.

senses.sense: (uncountable, figuratively) A fleeting illusion; something insubstantial, evanescent, unreal, transitory, or without result.
examples: The excitement behind the new candidate proved to be smoke.

senses.sense: (uncountable, figuratively) Something used to obscure or conceal; an obscuring condition; see also smoke and mirrors.
examples: The smoke of controversy.

senses.sense: (uncountable) A light grey colour/color tinted with blue.
(uncountable, slang) Bother; problems; hassle.
examples: You better not be giving me no smoke.

senses.sense: (military, uncountable) A particulate of solid or liquid particles dispersed into the air on the battlefield to degrade enemy ground or for aerial observation. Smoke has many uses--screening smoke, signaling smoke, smoke curtain, smoke haze, and smoke deception. Thus it is an artificial aerosol.
(baseball, slang) A fastball.
(countable) A distinct column of smoke, such as indicating a burning area or fire.
(transitive) To inhale and exhale the smoke from a burning cigarette, cigar, pipe, etc.
examples: He's smoking his pipe. Smoking a pipe has gone out of fashion.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To inhale and exhale tobacco smoke.
examples: Do you smoke?

senses.sense: (intransitive) To give off smoke.
examples: My old truck was still smoking even after the repairs.

senses.sense: (intransitive) Of a fire in a fireplace: to emit smoke outward instead of up the chimney, owing to imperfect draught.
(transitive) To preserve or prepare (food) for consumption by treating with smoke.
examples: You'll need to smoke the meat for several hours.

senses.sense: (transitive) To dry or medicate by smoke.
(transitive, obsolete) To fill or scent with smoke; hence, to fill with incense; to perfume.
(transitive, obsolete) To make unclear or blurry.
(intransitive, slang, mostly as present participle) To perform (e.g. music) energetically or skillfully.
examples: The horn section was really smokin' on that last tune.

senses.sense: (slang) To beat someone at something.
examples: We smoked them at rugby.

senses.sense: (transitive, slang) To kill, especially with a gun.
examples: He got smoked by the mob.

senses.sense: (transitive, slang, obsolete) To thrash; to beat.
